[1] In conclusion, the findings of the present study support the hypothesis that the presence of leukotriene B4 in exhaled breath condensate is most likely to be due to salivary contamination. [2] The differences in levels of leukotriene B4 in exhaled breath condensate that have been reported between different groups of patients, or between patients and healthy controls, are generally relatively modest and may, as discussed, be explained by other mechanisms than true differences in recovery of leukotriene B4 from the lower airways. [3] It remains to be seen whether the present conclusion applies only to measurement of leukotriene B4 in exhaled breath condensate, but it is hypothesised that the salivary origin of material in exhaled breath condensate is likely to be a major confounding factor for all compounds that are secreted in relatively high quantities in the saliva. [4] In order to test this possibility, future measurements in exhaled breath condensate need to include a sensitive Î±-amylase assay and measurements of the particular compound studied in saliva. [5] It is apparent that many publications reporting levels of leukotrienes in exhaled breath condensate do not present values on Î±-amylase activity.
